dc:description:
RHOG deficiency was reported in relation to autosomal recessive hemaphagocytic lmphohistiocytosis in 2021 (Kalinichenko et al. PMID: 33513601). This is the only report associated with huma RhoG deficiency. The only proband presented marked cytopenias with low leukocytes and thrombocytes, low hemoglobin, hypertriglyceridemia, raised ferritin, and plasma soluble interleukin-2 receptor. The patient met the eight clinical criteria for HLH with a very early onset of didease (4 months of age). 
The patient is heterozygous compound for RhoG deficiency. The paternal allele carried a deletion that contains the entire RHOG gene (chr11:3848730-3881730); the maternal allele carries a missense mutation: c.511G>A; p.Glu171Lys. The patient cells showed null expression of RhoG and overexpression of the missense variant confirmed that the expression is severely reduced compared to WT RhoG protein. 
Experimental evidence includes RhoG expression in relevant tissues such as lymphocytes (Natural Killer cells, T and B lymphocytes), fibroblast. PMID: 35280994. Defective lytic activity and degranulation in NK cells and CD8+ T cells from patient cells. RHOG KO NK-92 Cell lines edited by CRISPcas9 showed that when cells do not express RHOG there is decreased lytic activity and degranulation as seen in patients’ cells. Moreover, RHOG KO mice model showed elevated immunoglobulin levels similar to the human RHOG deficiency. Neither KO mice or Patient T lymphocytes showed affected activation.
In summary, RHOG deficiency is moderate associated with autosomal recessive familial hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis.

evidence.dc:description: The score was decreased half points because the mice model only shares the elevated IgG phenotype with the RHOG human deficiency.
KO mice showed elevated IgG levels
evidence.rdfs:label: RHOG KO mice

evidence.dc:description: RHOG KO NK92 cells were generated to prove the causality of HLH. The KO NK-92 cells showed a severe decrease in lysis effect and decreased degranulation, similar to the patient´s cells carrying two loss of function variants in RHOG.
evidence.rdfs:label: RHOG KO NK CELL LINES

evidence.dc:description:
NK cells and CD8 T cells showed decreased lysis activity on primary NK cells with or without IL-2. The degranulation was almost abolished in NK cells evaluated through the expression of CD107a.
Moreover, CD8 lysis and degranulation were impaired in CD8+ T cells.
evidence.rdfs:label: NK cells and CD8+ T cells Cytotoxicity

evidence.dc:description: Through affinity purification of Strephemagglutinin-tagged RhoG with subsequent mass spectrometry, it was identified that RhoG protein partners with Munc13-4. This interaction was confirmed by colocalization by microscopy.
evidence.rdfs:label: RhoG regulates exocytosis through interactions with Munc13-4

evidence.dc:description: RhoG protein is express in natural killer cells and T and B lymphocytes
evidence.rdfs:label: RHOG expression in lymphoid tissue

evidence.dc:description: qPCR was performed to detect CNV in proband and father, it was found a decrease of 0.53 and 0.62 fold, respectively.
Overexpression of the missense variant (c.511G>A; p.Glu171Lys) in HEK293 showed a significant decrease in expression, confirming the mutation's deleterious effect on RhoG protein stability.

evidence.rdfs:label: P1-Blood 2021
evidence.detectionMethod: Whole Exome Sequencing revealed two candidate variants in RHOG. The maternal allele carries a missense mutation (c.511G>A; p.Glu171Lys), and the paternal allele contains a 33-kb deletion (Chr11.3848730-3881730). Through qPCR, the reduction of CNV in the father and proband was detected.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Targeted sequencing for established Familial Hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (fHLH) did not identify any candidate gene/variant.
